G.L. c. 208, \\u00a7 28.proposition: NOW COMES the Plaintiff, Jessica Taylor ("Plaintiff"), and files this Complaint for Modification of the existing custody order pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28 and G.L. c. 209C, § 20.

G.L. c. 209C, \\u00a7 20.proposition: NOW COMES the Plaintiff, Jessica Taylor ("Plaintiff"), and files this Complaint for Modification of the existing custody order pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28 and G.L. c. 209C, § 20.

G.L. c. 209C, \\u00a7 1.proposition: This Court retains jurisdiction over the matter as it pertains to custody and the parenting plan of the minor child pursuant to G.L. c. 209C, § 1 and relevant Massachusetts law.

*Schaffer v. Schaffer*, 72 Mass. App. Ct.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a modification of custody or visitation requires a showing of a material and substantial change in circumstances since the entry of the prior order and that the requested modification is in the best interest of the child.
*Schaffer v. Schaffer*, 72 Mass. App. Ct.support_reasoning: The provided opinion text is not Schaffer v. Schaffer and does not concern custody or visitation modification standards. It is a criminal case about providing alcohol to minors, addressing search and seizure, jury instructions, Fifth Amendment issues, and a motion for new trial. It does not discuss the requirement of a material and substantial change in circumstances or best interests of the child for modification of custody or visitation, so it cannot support the stated proposition.
*Schaffer v. Schaffer*, 72 Mass. App. Ct.relevant_excerpt: The opinion deals entirely with criminal charges for providing alcohol to minors, exigent circumstances for a warrantless search, jury instructions, Fifth Amendment rights of witnesses, and denial of a motion for new trial; it contains no discussion of child custody, visitation, or modification standards.

*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488, 492 (20.proposition: Courts consider the current and future needs of the child and whether the existing parenting plan serves the child’s best interests.
*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488, 492 (20.support_reasoning: The court explicitly articulates and applies the best-interests standard in custody decisions, noting that judges must weigh all relevant factors and assess them in light of the particular needs and circumstances of the child, including present and prospective living conditions. The opinion evaluates the child’s attachments, stability of each home, work schedules, and the impact of future relocation, reflecting consideration of both current and future needs and whether the parenting plan serves the child’s best interests.
*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488, 492 (20.relevant_excerpt: “‘In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry [is] … what is ‘best for the child’…. However, the judge must weigh ‘all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child.’ … The best interests of the child standard is applied in the context of the particular needs and circumstances of the child in question. … The judge shall consider ‘whether or not the child’s present or past living conditions adversely affect his physical, mental, moral or emotional health.’ G. L. c. 208, § 31.”

*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..proposition: The stability, health, and well-being of the child are paramount considerations.
*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion expressly states that in removal cases, although the custodial parent’s interests are relevant, the best interests of the children remain the paramount concern. The court then explains that evaluating the child’s best interests requires focusing on the effect of removal on the child’s life, including emotional, physical, and developmental needs, confirming that the child’s well-being is paramount in the analysis.
*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “As most recently reformulated by the Supreme Court of New Jersey in Cooper v. Cooper, 99 N.J. 42 (1984), the ‘real advantage’ test is grounded on the ‘realization that after a divorce a child’s subsequent relationship with both parents can never be the same as before the divorce . . . [and] that the child’s quality of life and style of life are provided by the custodial parent.’ Id. at 53. Although the best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern, ‘[b]ecause the best interests of a child are so interwoven with the well-being of the custodial parent, the determination of the child’s best interest requires that the interests of the custodial parent be taken into account.’ Id. at 54.”

*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398,.proposition: The stability, health, and well-being of the child are paramount considerations.
*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398,.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely addresses custody standards and repeatedly emphasizes that the court’s “overriding concern” is the children’s best interests, happiness, and welfare, including their present and probable future well-being. In upholding the custody award and visitation limits, the court focuses on minimizing disruption and fostering a healthy environment for the children, making clear that the children’s stability, welfare, and development are paramount considerations in custody determinations.
*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398,.relevant_excerpt: “However, in deciding issues involving custody, the overriding concern of the court must be the promotion of the best interests of the children and their general welfare. … ‘[T]he happiness and the welfare of the children] should be the controlling consideration. It is the duty of the judge to consider the welfare of the children] in reference not merely to the present, but also to the probable future….’ … These factors are highly significant for the welfare of the children, and are thus critical considerations for the judge in deciding on a custodial arrangement which minimizes disruption and fosters a healthy environment….”

*Prenaveau v. Prenaveau*, 81 Mass. App..proposition: A modification is warranted when the existing schedule no longer effectively serves the child’s needs due to a change in circumstances.
*Prenaveau v. Prenaveau*, 81 Mass. App..support_reasoning: The opinion is a removal/custody appeal, not a modification case, and it does not articulate a rule that a parenting plan should be changed when the existing schedule no longer serves the child’s needs. Instead, the court emphasizes stability and continuity, and reverses the trial judge’s relocation order as an abuse of discretion because the existing arrangement in Stoughton was satisfactory and there were no compelling reasons to uproot the children. While it discusses when a change in residence is or is not justified, it does not frame this in terms of a general modification standard tied to a change in circumstances rendering the schedule ineffective.
*Prenaveau v. Prenaveau*, 81 Mass. App..relevant_excerpt: “In most cases, ... if the child has been living with one parent for some time, the child’s needs are being adequately met under that parent’s care, and that parent is capable of continuing to care for the child, it is not in the child’s best interests to disrupt that successful arrangement. Rather, it is in the child’s best interests to preserve it. Belief that the other parent might be a little better in some areas ought not suffice to disrupt a child’s satisfactory home life with the caretaker parent.” Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 844 (2003), quoted in this case.

*Hale v. Hale*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812, 8.proposition: Courts recognize that maintaining strong and meaningful relationships with both parents serves a child’s best interests.
*Hale v. Hale*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812, 8.support_reasoning: The case discusses relocation in terms of the children’s best interests and explicitly recognizes the importance of maintaining and fostering the relationship between the children and the noncustodial parent, including through alternative visitation schedules. While the opinion’s primary focus is on integrating the custodial parent’s well-being into the best-interests analysis, it also recognizes that preserving meaningful parental relationships with both parents is an important component of that analysis. Thus it offers some support for the proposition, though not as a broad, standalone statement of that principle.
*Hale v. Hale*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812, 8.relevant_excerpt: “From what we can ascertain, the judge recognized the importance of the ‘frequent and continuing contact’ of the child with both its parents, Felton v. Felton, 383 Mass. at 234, quoting from Cal. Civ. Code § 4600 (West 1981 Supp.), and entered his judgment prohibiting removal on the basis that the move would make visitation more difficult. We consider that factor not in itself conclusive. … He did not discuss the possibility of alternate visiting schedules which would preserve and foster the important relationship of the children with their father.”

*Felton v. Felton*, 383 Mass. 232, 235-3.proposition: The Massachusetts Guidelines for Shared Parenting highlight the importance of both parents maintaining consistent and substantial contact with their child to provide emotional and developmental support.
*Felton v. Felton*, 383 Mass. 232, 235-3.support_reasoning: The opinion does not discuss the Massachusetts Guidelines for Shared Parenting at all, nor does it frame its analysis in terms of those guidelines. While it does recognize a general policy value in a child having “frequent and continuing contact” with both parents, that language is drawn from California law (Murga and Cal. Civ. Code § 4600), not Massachusetts shared parenting guidelines, and the focus is on religious-instruction limits in visitation, not shared parenting norms. Thus, the case cannot be cited as authority for what the Massachusetts Guidelines for Shared Parenting themselves highlight or provide.
*Felton v. Felton*, 383 Mass. 232, 235-3.relevant_excerpt: “The law, however, tolerates and even encourages up to a point the child’s exposure to the religious influences of both parents although they are divided in their faiths. This, we think, is because the law sees a value in ‘frequent and continuing contact’ of the child with both its parents (Murga, supra, 103 Cal. App. 3d at 503, quoting from Cal. Civ. Code § 4600 [West 1981]) and thus contact with the parents’ separate religious preferences.”

*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: Here, the Defendant’s improved living conditions and the evolving needs of Daniel constitute material changes in circumstances that justify modifying the current parenting arrangement.
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: The case is a removal/relocation decision in a joint physical custody context, not a modification case based on a parent’s improved circumstances or evolving child needs. The court applies a best-interests standard to deny the relocating parent’s request and explicitly affirms continuation of shared physical custody; it does not discuss improved living conditions or changing child needs as constituting a material change warranting modification. Thus, it does not support the proposition that such changes justify modifying the current parenting arrangement.
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “We turn to the propriety of the judge’s order denying permission for the mother to remove the children. The order is based on the judge’s findings that the children’s best interests would be negatively affected by this move. … The judge … did not award sole physical custody to either party, deciding instead to order continued shared legal and physical custody. The mother appealed… Her findings regarding the situation are warranted by the evidence and, based on them, her conclusion that removal is not in the children’s best interests is not an abuse of discretion.”

*Schechter v. Schechter*, 88 Mass. App..proposition: The modification will provide Daniel with a stable, predictable parenting plan more suited to his developmental stage and his expressed desire to spend overnight time with the Defendant.
*Schechter v. Schechter*, 88 Mass. App..support_reasoning: The opinion does not discuss any modification granting Daniel (the child) a new parenting plan, nor does it mention providing him with a more stable or predictable plan tailored to his developmental stage or expressed desire for overnights with the father. Instead, the case affirms a one-year suspension of all contact between the father and the child and critiques an overbroad removal provision, with no language about a modified plan increasing overnight time with the father. Thus, it does not support the proposition stated.
*Schechter v. Schechter*, 88 Mass. App..relevant_excerpt: “The judgment ordered that the mother have sole legal and physical custody of the child and that ‘[t]here shall be a one year cessation of any contact between [the child] and his father.’ … The findings are amply supported by the evidence and demonstrate that the decision to suspend the father’s visitation rights with the child was based on the exercise of a sound discretion.”
